body: Ok, backport is #2623
maybe we should backport this to 0.9.0 as avro is new and it would be good to have nice docs out of the gate.
@gianm please backport
Backported in #2626
Odd, master reported error in build after this: https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/jobs/114963680 might have been transient
thanks to @guobingkun for testing and showing the failure.
can we have some UTs ?
Thanks @himanshug !  Verified it fixed the issue.
@b-slim its hard to have UT for this specific case because things are supposed to succeed even when location find code fails. there are tests for rest of the code already.
@drcrallen integration test will not catch it because again even if location finding fails, overall ingestion would still succeed.
also, we already have the pseudo-integration test for testing the overall feature in BatchDeltaIngestionTest .
@himanshug backport pl0x
@jon-wei added comment.

Yes: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/4cc81d3efff03ae59f31e7bffe0d924a2f0dbbe3/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/query/filter/InDimFilter.java

FWIW, you may want to use https://github.com/implydata/plyql for SQL
use groupBys instead of topNs is the big one, although for topNs, if you issue a top 1000 query, the first 900 or so elements are going to be 100% accurate most likely

"100% accurate most likely" is kind of a funny statement :)

You should avoid these approximate features if you need 100% guaranteed accuracy:
- topN queries
- cardinality, approxHistogram, hyperUnique aggregators

These features are exact:
- groupBy, timeseries queries
- *Sum, *Max, *Min, count aggregators

Although keep in mind that many computations in Druid are floating-point, and depending on how serious your accuracy needs are, it may matter to you than even our exact algorithms may be using floating-point numbers.

Closing this issue - if you have further questions, please use the mailing list (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/druid-user).
@sirpkt my mistake, yes it's all UTC by default, so I'm ok adding those.

:+1:

This can be for later, but any thoughts on whether it's useful to expand this with more supported math expressions? e.g. trigonometric functions, ln, e^x?
I agree with @gianm's comments. @navis thoughts?

@himanshug updated with most of your review comments addressed, but I am not entirely sure what you mean on the thread w/ https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2220#discussion_r55778213.
@gianm backport?
Sorry I've seen this just now. My bad.
LGTM after taking care of minor comments.

@xvrl Thank you for the comments.
Updated based on the review comments

I spoke with @gianm about this last night on the way back, and it seems that "examples" really is just "twitter spritzer firehose" and isn't used anywhere.

Given such, would it make sense to move the spritzer into a more descriptive location, or remove it completely since it is not used in the quickstart? @fjy

I'll do a backport for this (mostly so we can reduce the tarball size) although given @drcrallen comments we may want to do further adjustments for 0.9.1.

sounds good?
@drcrallen anything is blocking this ?
@jon-wei yes, I will be adding more math functions, this PR sets up the framework really... adding more math functions would be trivial.

Filed #2637 for this transient test failure.

```
Tests run: 4, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 6.356 sec <<< FAILURE! - in io.druid.indexing.worker.WorkerTaskMonitorTest
testRestartCleansOldStatus(io.druid.indexing.worker.WorkerTaskMonitorTest)  Time elapsed: 1.213 sec  <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<FAILED> but was:<RUNNING>
    at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
    at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:743)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:118)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:144)
    at io.druid.indexing.worker.WorkerTaskMonitorTest.testRestartCleansOldStatus(WorkerTaskMonitorTest.java:338)
```
This test is simulating a restart, this is possibly caused by the old WTM not fully exiting.
:+1: after travis passes and if https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2631/files#diff-f49e61add183134417ea5acad8acb683R283 is supposed to silently ignore agg parse exceptions

Saw this failure #2253 

https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/builds/115210472
https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/builds/115210472
@pjain1, yes it should ignore agg parse exceptions if "reportParseExceptions" is false (although now it will at least debug log them)
Suggest adding sanity check in start to ensure latch hasn't already fired, like if getCount is not 1 throw ISE on start.
that way noone in the future can start this twice.
@drcrallen I think the sanity checks already there will prevent starting twice. (ISE gets thrown if "started" or "exec.isShutdown" is true)
ah, good call, :+1:  then
@b-slim https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2517#discussion_r55877524
@drcrallen thanks i have added lock
@navis can you squash commits?
@b-slim added config
:+1: after travis
@fjy I have refined this PR with docs and more tests. Ready to review.
whoa reactions are cool
@fjy squshed.

@fjy @gianm I think this might be better in extension. This is good example of extending `DimFilter` which is currently not possible but now possible with newly introduced `DimFilterExtension` interface in this patch. And also I'm a little concerned of using undocumented semantic of `Indexed.indexOf()`.
@nishantmonu51 looks good other than some minor comments, let me know when you are ready and I can take another look
BTW this might be related to: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2604

What did you do to cause that error? We have been running with this change for over a month now.
@himanshug Is it necessary to remove our toy-sql runner? :)
@drcrallen This is squashed and addressed all the comments, can we get this in, it is blocking me please.
@erikdubbelboer can google cloud storage handle ':' in the path names?
:+1: @gianm looks good overall, can you pls cleanup your commit history as needed.
also, it appears that google cloud storage can be used via native hdfs filesystem implementation?

@himanshug yes it handles ':' in path names normally. To use google cloud storage with hadoop you need the gs:// paths. Otherwise it will just store the files in the normal hdfs filesystem. As far as I know it's not possible to tell hadoop to store hdfs:// files in google cloud storage. See https://cloud.google.com/hadoop/google-cloud-storage-connector

We have been using this patch for over a month now to store our indexes in hadoop on google cloud storage.

@navis had to remove that because it was written with an older version of antlr and was broken with antlr4. older version required writing grammar and implementation details in the same file which was messy.

@sirpkt Are you using Kafka to ingest data? If so, I strongly suggest you look at the Kafka Index Task from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2220. We have a few more PRs coming after that is merged which will provide exactly-once consumption of data from Kafka.
@himanshug I had it split up as 6 commit on purpose (I think the 6 commits are pretty distinct), do you think I should combine some of them?
i did say, "as needed" in there. if its already done then, great. :+1:
cool, just checking :smile:
@drcrallen @gianm handed review comments, please check again.

and, does google cloud storage come with an implementation of hadoop FileSystem api which you use in your hadoop jobs to read/write data in gs://path/ and use hdfs deep storage with that FileSystem impl at historicals etc to load the data?
:+1: after travis

@michaelschiff Unfortunately no - hostname change didn't help, and I saw no exceptions in the log. My attention has shifted, so I wasn't able to explore further at this time.

@danosipov no worries if you don't have time to check, but how did you build? Are you sure the jars are on your classpath?
`java-statsd-client-3.0.1.jar statsd-emitter-0.9.0-SNAPSHOT.jar`
I believe the JARs were on the classpath - but I'll check next time I try it

:+1: 

FWIW, I think it'd be awesome to have a Hadoop test farm where integration tests run against different versions of Hadoop and ppl can contribute their own versions
